Award.AwardTitle: Flutter Analysis and Control for Elastic Structure in Axial Air Flow: Applications to Palatal Flutter and Energy Harvesting
Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this project is to carry out a detailed analysis of a mathematical model of an elastic solid structure (a long thin rectangular plate) interacting with an axial air flow (a flow parallel to the plate?s axis), and based on the results of this analysis, to investigate the problem of a flutter control for the structure. The dynamics of the plate is governed by a system of two coupled hyperbolic partial differential equations known in aeroelasticity as the Goland model. The airflow, which is a small perturbation of a stream parallel to the main plate's axis, is assumed to be inviscid, potential, isentropic, and subsonic. The dynamics of the airflow is governed by the Euler hydrodynamic equation. Owing to the above physical assumptions, the Euler equation can be reduced to a single three-dimensional linear hyperbolic equation for the perturbation potential. This equation is coupled with the system of structural equations by a set of specific boundary conditions: (a) the flow-tangency condition, (b) the Kutta-Joukowski condition, and (c) the far-field condition. The goals of the project include the following: (a) asymptotic, spectral, and stability analysis of the model, (b) analysis of possible flutter control mechanisms, (c) generalization of linear model to the model involving nonlinear structural equations (the Dowell-Hodges model) and investigation of flutter as limit cycle oscillations. The model has two major practical applications: (a) flutter of a soft palate (the palatal flutter) resulting in snoring and sleep apnoea, (b) piezoelectric power harvesting. The project is a continuation of the PI's 12-year work on asymptotic, spectral, and stability analysis and on flutter control for aircraft wing models.

Examples of solid structures interacting with an air or fluid flow include: aircraft wings and tails, suspension bridges, electric power lines, walls of blood vessels and bronchial airways, etc. The phenomenon that unites all the examples is flutter, i.e., sudden chaotic vibrations of the structure, which occur when the speed of the air or fluid flow reaches certain critical value called the utter speed. The project deals with theoretical analysis of a recently developed mathematical model of an elastic solid plate in an axial air flow (an air flow parallel to the plate's main axis). An experimental and computational investigation of the model has already begun in the scientific community. However, an importance of theoretical analysis is obvious: it can provide new insights and is necessary for a design of flutter control mechanisms. The axial flow case is more challenging than a normal flow case (the flow is perpendicular to the plate?s main axis), which occurs in all aircraft wing models. One of the two major applications of the model is medical, which deals with palatal utter: uncontrolled vibrations of a soft palate resulting in snoring and even sleep apnoae. Currently, treatments involve surgical procedures and designing anti-snoring devices. The second application is a newly emerging area of piezoelectric energy harvesting from utter vibrations. The goal of this research direction is to develop a new technology for providing alternative sources of electric power and/or recharging storage devices such as batteries or capacitors. The concept has ecological ramifications in reducing the chemical waste and potential monetary gains by significantly reducing maintenance cost.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project outcome report

Several groups of results have been obtained under the support of this award.

1. The first group of results deals with a rigorous analysis of a mathematical model of an aircraft wing in a subsonic nonviscous incompressible airflow. The main focus of the research was the location of the socalled aeroelastic modes. This is an infinite sequence of complex numbers (poles of the so-called generalized resolvent) that characterize the vibrational frequencies of the wing. The modes depend on the speed of the airflow and on the air density (i.e., on the speed of the aircraft and the altitude). Those modes that are located in the right half plane of the complex plane describe unstable vibrations of the wing, i.e. they are the fluttering modes. The PI has proven that there exist only a finite number of fluttering modes and they are located in a “circle of instability". A formula for the radius of the circle in terms of airflow speed and density has been derived by the PI.

2. The second group of results deals with a rigorous analysis of a mathematical model of an energy harvester. The harvester is represented as an elastic beam with attached piezoelectric patches. The beam vibrates under the influence of an ambient airflow and the energy of vibrations is transformed into an electric output due to the piezoelectric effect. The model is governed by a system of
differential equations. The PI investigated the so – called dynamics generator of the model and obtained the following results: derived asymptotic formulas for the eigenvalues (the vibration frequencies); proved the basis property of the eigenvectors (the vibration modes); discovered that the eigenvectors form the so-called Bari basis (the one that is quadratically close to an orthonormal basis). These results were applied by the PI to a solution of a number of control problems for the harvester model. In particular, the PI discovered that the interpolation theory in the spaces of analytic functions is the key ingredient in the solution of the so – called output tracking problem
for the harvester model.

3. The third group of results deals with the control and stability analysis of some classical beam models with non-dissipative bounding conditions (i.e., the energy of the beam with these conditions is not a decreasing function of time). The PI has shown that, in spite of the fact that the boundary conditions are nondissipative, the system is nevertheless stable for some ranges of the control parameters.

4. The fourth group of results is obtained by the PI in collaboration with the PI’s Ph.D. student. It is devoted to control problems and stability analysis for the well-known torsion-vibration model with non-dissipative boundary conditions. This model is used to describe the ground vibrations of an aircraft wing (i.e., vibrations when the speed of the airflow is zero).

5. The fifth group of results deals with the so-called non-local model of a multi-walled carbon nanotube. These results include asymptotic, spectral, and stability analysis of the model.


Last Modified: 06/07/2017
Modified by: Marianna A Shubov
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Project outcome report Several groups of results have been obtained under the support of this award. 1. The first group of results deals with a rigorous analysis of a mathematical model of an aircraft wing in a subsonic nonviscous incompressible airflow. The main focus of the research was the location of the socalled aeroelastic modes. This is an infinite sequence of complex numbers (poles of the so-called generalized resolvent) that characterize the vibrational frequencies of the wing. The modes depend on the speed of the airflow and on the air density (i.e., on the speed of the aircraft and the altitude). Those modes that are located in the right half plane of the complex plane describe unstable vibrations of the wing, i.e. they are the fluttering modes. The PI has proven that there exist only a finite number of fluttering modes and they are located in a "circle of instability". A formula for the radius of the circle in terms of airflow speed and density has been derived by the PI. 2. The second group of results deals with a rigorous analysis of a mathematical model of an energy harvester. The harvester is represented as an elastic beam with attached piezoelectric patches. The beam vibrates under the influence of an ambient airflow and the energy of vibrations is transformed into an electric output due to the piezoelectric effect. The model is governed by a system of differential equations. The PI investigated the so – called dynamics generator of the model and obtained the following results: derived asymptotic formulas for the eigenvalues (the vibration frequencies); proved the basis property of the eigenvectors (the vibration modes); discovered that the eigenvectors form the so-called Bari basis (the one that is quadratically close to an orthonormal basis). These results were applied by the PI to a solution of a number of control problems for the harvester model. In particular, the PI discovered that the interpolation theory in the spaces of analytic functions is the key ingredient in the solution of the so – called output tracking problem for the harvester model. 3. The third group of results deals with the control and stability analysis of some classical beam models with non-dissipative bounding conditions (i.e., the energy of the beam with these conditions is not a decreasing function of time). The PI has shown that, in spite of the fact that the boundary conditions are nondissipative, the system is nevertheless stable for some ranges of the control parameters. 4. The fourth group of results is obtained by the PI in collaboration with the PI?s Ph.D. student. It is devoted to control problems and stability analysis for the well-known torsion-vibration model with non-dissipative boundary conditions. This model is used to describe the ground vibrations of an aircraft wing (i.e., vibrations when the speed of the airflow is zero). 5. The fifth group of results deals with the so-called non-local model of a multi-walled carbon nanotube. These results include asymptotic, spectral, and stability analysis of the model.
